title: Nancy Hanks (horse)
text:
Nancy Hanks (1886–August 16, 1915) was an undefeated <a href="Standardbred">Standardbred</a> <a href="harness%20racing">trotting</a> mare named for <a href="Abraham%20Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a>s <a href="Nancy%20Hanks">mother</a>. She was the first 2:05 trotter in harness-racing history.
She was foaled in 1886 on what is now known as Poplar Hill Farm, near <a href="Lexington%2C%20Kentucky">Lexington, Kentucky</a>. Bred by Hart Boswell, she was sired by Happy Medium; her dam, Nancy Lee, was by Dictator.
While owned by <a href="John%20Malcolm%20Forbes">John Malcolm Forbes</a>, on September 28, 1892 the brown mare trotted a mile in 2 minutes and 4 seconds at <a href="Terre%20Haute">Terre Haute</a>'s Four Cornered Track with a bicycle sulky, breaking all Sunol's mark of 2 minutes 8.25 seconds set in 1891. Nancy Hanks lost one race heat (in her first start), but was undefeated in her races. She was inducted into the <a href="Harness%20Racing%20Museum%20%26amp%3B%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Harness Racing Museum & Hall of Fame</a> in 1955.
Nancy Hanks died on August 16, 1915 at age 29, and is buried in the <a href="John%20E.%20Madden">Hamburg Place</a> equine cemetery. A statue of her was created by sculptor <a href="Charles%20Cary%20Rumsey">Charles Cary Rumsey</a>.
A <a href="Nancy%20Hanks%20%28train%29">passenger train</a> from Atlanta to Savannah from 1947 to 1971 was named in her honor.
